titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the
Gramercy Neighborhood Associates Records
1828–2009 (bulk, 1912–2009)
PR 370
titlestmt.author: Zora Arum and Joseph Ditta

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-04-12 14:08:02 -0400.

did.abstract: The collection primarily consists of photographs of Gramercy Park and the surrounding area, including street, park, building exteriors, and aerial views. There are also eight fiction and non-fiction books about Gramercy Park and related historical figures.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers by appointment only.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Gramercy Neighborhood Associates in two parts: accession PPAC-2017-064 (received September 2017) and accession PPAC-2019-016 (received March 2019).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection organized in six series:

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Gramercy Park Association organized February 7, 1912. "At the Annual Meeting on Jan. 19, 1966 a resolution was adopted instructing the Executive Committee to take all necessary steps to obtain tax exemption for the Association and for donors of gifts to it. Counsel was employed. He reported that we would have to form a new corporation under a section of the NY law in order to qualify under state laws and Internal Revenue Regulations for exemption. Gramercy Neighborhood Associates, Inc. was duly organized, and on August 31, 1966 the Internal Revenue Service issued its approval of the corporation as a Charitable Organization entitled to exemption."
"The First Meeting of the Board of Directors of the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates, Inc., was held on June 29, 1966, at the National Arts Club . . ."
Not to be confused with "Gramercy Neighborhood Association," an anti-vice organization active circa 1913, or with the "Trustees of Gramercy Park," who control access to the park itself.

Gramercy Neighborhood Associates is a nonprofit organization made up primarily of Gramercy Park residents. The organization was founded in 1912, in part united by a collective effort to prevent the passage of a bill that would have bisected Gramercy Park in order to connect Lexington Avenue and Irving Place. Since then, Gramercy Neighborhood Associates has engaged in a variety of community service projects, including hosting events for residents such as the Annual Art Show, sponsoring neighborhood renovations such as replacing modern lampposts with Bishop Crook Lampposts in order to reestablish Gramercy's historic aesthetic, and engaging with schools and local businesses in the Gramercy Park area.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
The collection should be cited as the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates Records, PR 370, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Credit Line (for exhibitions): Gift of the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates, 2017, 2019.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Archival intern Zora Arum processed this collection's initial accession of eight books and nine folders of photographs (PPAC-2017-064) in September 2018. Archivist Joseph Ditta revised her finding aid to incorporate the subsequent, larger accession (PPAC-2019-016) in December 2020-January 2021.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers interested in the Gramercy Park Flower Show (see Series III) may also wish to consult the Horticultural Society of New York Records, 1811-circa 2010 (MS 3033).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of approximately 150 photographs and eight fiction and non-fiction books about Gramercy Park and related historical figures.

The photographs are of Gramercy Park and its surrounding areas, including Union Square Park, Madison Square Park, Stuyvesant Town, and Peter Cooper Village. Most of the photographs are reproductions of images from the mid 1800s through the twentieth century, though there are many original documents found throughout. The earliest original photograph appears to date from about 1892. The photographs are mainly views of streets, parks and building exteriors, along with a number of aerial shots. Images of buildings include a few under construction, such as the Flatiron Building (1902) and the Metropolitan Life Insurance building (1907-08). All of the photos are black-and-white, except for a set from 1989 taken by Consolidated Edison. The container list provides further detail, and Folder 1 contains a detailed inventory provided by the donor of the photographs' subjects.
The books in the collection are listed individually in the container list.
All materials in the collection appear to have been compiled by the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates, but do not pertain to the organization itself.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Information on the formation of the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopy of invitation from Cyrus W. Field to Henry L. Grant (1820–1894) to attend the eightieth birthday of Field's brother, David Dudley Field (1805–1894). The Field brothers lived on the site of No. 1 Lexington Avenue at the corner of Gramercy Park North.

did.unittitle: John B. Pine's The Story of Gramercy Park, 1831–1921

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An advertisement and promotional material for John B. Pine's book, The Story of Gramercy Park, 1831–1921 (for a copy, see Subseries V.A). Includes a 1919 letter from Alexander Duane to Pine informing him that he lacks a print or description of his great-great-grandfather's county seat on Gramercy Park.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to Raymond Walburn of Beverly Hills, California, from Ronald Regan, as president of the Screen Actors Guild, discussing MOVIETIME U.S.A., a nationwide promotional tour campaign of Hollywood personalities. It is unclear why this letter is in the present collection, unless Gramercy Park was one of the locations of a celebrity visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documentations of efforts by Gramercy Neighborhood Associates to replace the area's modern lampposts with historic reproductions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ludwig Bemelmans, perhaps best remembered for creating the beloved children's book character "Madeline," was a longtime resident of Gramercy Park. He died in 1962 at the National Arts Club (15 Gramercy Park South).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stained glass artist Elskus designed windows for the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany, 375 Second Avenue.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The handwritten page numbers on some images refer to Stephen Garmey's Gramercy Park: An Illustrated History of a New York Neighborhood (1984). For a copy of the book, see Subseries V.A.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Filed geographically, starting with Gramercy Park and the streets fronting it (Gramercy Park North, South, East, and West), followed by numbered Manhattan streets (running east-west), numbered and named Manhattan avenues (running north-south), squares, aerial views, unidentified locations, and people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Gramercy Park proper, including its paths, plantings, statuary, fountains, and fence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Artistic depictions of Gramercy Park from The Saturday Evening Post, October 12, 1946 and January 3, 1948.

did.unittitle: Gramercy Park asbestos steam explosion cleanup

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Color photographs (including aerial views) documenting the cleanup efforts by Consolidated Edison following a steam pipe explosion outside 32 Gramercy Park South (southwest corner of East 20th Street and Third Avenue) that killed three people, injured twenty-four, and released a cloud of asbestos over the neighborhood on August 19, 1989.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the buildings fronting Gramercy Park North (a.k.a. East 21st Street), including the residence of architect Stanford White (121 East 21st Street).

Ruggles; Augustus Saint-Gaudens's relief of Richard Watson Gilder with his wife, Helena De Kay, and son, Rodman; members of the National Arts Club and Gramercy Neighborhood Associates caroling at Christmas, 1974; and an unidentifed man writing at a desk (possibly John B. Pine, author of The Story of Gramercy Park, 1831–1921?).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many issues carry contributions by longtime Gramercy Neighborhood Associates archivist Stephen Garmey.
Vol. 3: no. 1 (1988), no. 3 (Spring/Summer 1989)
Vol. 4: no. 1 (Winter 1990), no. 2 (Spring/Summer 1990), no. 3 (Fall 1990) [2 copies], no. 4 (Winter/Spring 1991)

Vol. 7: no. 1 (Summer 1994), no. 2 (Fall 1994), no. 3 (Winter 1995), no. 4 (Spring 1995)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: ....Map of James Duane's land, measured in acres, rods, and perches (1763 November 5)
....Map of the six acres James Duane bought from John Watts Jr. to complete Gramercy Farm (1786)
....Map of Gramercy Farm, drawn for Samuel B. Ruggles (1831)
.....Edwin Smith, surveyor. Map of the Lower Division of the Lands of Samuel B. Ruggles in the Twelfth Ward of the City of New York (1831 December 31)
Egbert Ludovicus Viele. Sanitary & Topographical Map of the city and island of New York [detail] (1864/65)
.....John B. Holmes, surveyor. Map of Rose Hill Farm, Gramercy seat, and the Estate of John Watts (1866 November)
....."Gramercy Park as of 1852" from Kenneth Holcomb Dunshee's As You Pass By (1952)
....Zoning map of the Gramercy Park neighborhood showing residence, business, and unrestricted districts.
